column1: Osnabrück (German pronunciation: [ɔsnaˈbʁʏk] (listen); Westphalian: Ossenbrügge; archaic Osnaburg) is a city in the federal state of Lower Saxony in north-west Germany. It is situated in a valley penned between the Wiehen Hills and the northern tip of the Teutoburg Forest. With a population of 168
column2: 145 Osnabrück is one of the four largest cities in Lower Saxony. The city is the centrepoint of the Osnabrück Land region as well as the District of Osnabrück.The founding of Osnabrück was linked to its positioning on important European trading routes. Charles the Great founded the Diocese of Osnabrück in 780. The city was also a member of the Hanseatic League. At the end of the Thirty Years' War (1618–1648)
column3: the Peace of Westphalia was negotiated in Osnabrück and the nearby city of Münster. In recognition of its role as the site of negotiations
column4: Osnabrück later adopted the title Friedensstadt ("city of peace"). The city is also known as the birthplace of anti-war novelist Erich-Maria Remarque and painter Felix Nussbaum.

column1: More recently Osnabrück has become well known for its industry. Numerous companies in the automobile
column2: paper
column3: steel and grocery sectors are located in the city and its surrounding area. In spite of the massive destruction inflicted on the city during World War II
column4: the Altstadt (old town) was eventually reconstructed extensively with designs loyal to the original medieval architecture there. Osnabrück was also the home of the largest British garrison outside the United Kingdom. Osnabrück's modern
column5: urban image is enhanced by the presence of more than 22
column6: 000 students studying at the University and the University of Applied Sciences. Although part of the state of Lower Saxony
column8: culturally and linguistically Osnabrück is considered part of the region of Westphalia.

column1: The origin of the name Osnabrück is disputed. The suffix -brück suggests a bridge over or to something (from German Brücke = bridge) but the prefix Osna- is explained in at least two different ways: the traditional explanation is that today's name is a corruption of Ossenbrügge (westphalian meaning "oxen bridge")
column2: which is etymologically and historically impossible
column3: because the town is older than this corruption of consonants (documented in 13. century
column4: Osnabrueck was founded in 8. century)
column5: but others state that it is derived from the name of the Hase River which is arguably derived from Asen (Æsir)
column6: thus giving Osnabrück the meaning "bridge to the gods"
column7: and previously Tacitus named people living near the grey river (Hase) Chasuarii. From Slavic languages osna means as much as the forest land/forest area "osna" /"osina"/"osnic".It may also be noted that Osnabrueck is situated on the northern end of the Teutoberg Forest
column8: which until the 19th century was known as the Osning. The way in which the city's name is pronounced can also serve as a means of telling if the speaker is a native of Osnabrück or a visitor: most locals stress the last syllable
column9: while those from elsewhere tend to stress the first one.

column1: The city gave its name to the textile fabric of osnaburg (note: "-burg" means borough).
Osnabrück initially developed as a marketplace next to the bishopric founded by Charlemagne
column2: King of the Franks
column4: the city became the seat of the Prince-Bishopric of Osnabrück.  Although the precise date is uncertain
column5: it is likely that Osnabrück is the oldest bishopric in Lower Saxony.

column1: In the year 804 Charlemagne was said to have founded the Gymnasium Carolinum in Osnabrück.  This would make it the oldest German Gymnasium school
column2: but the charter date is disputed by historians
column3: some of whom believe it could be a forgery.

column1: In 889 the town was given merchant
column2: customs
column3: and coinage privileges by King Arnulf of Carinthia. Osnabrück was first referred to in records as a "city" in 1147. A decade later
column4: Emperor Frederick Barbarossa granted the city fortification privileges (Befestigungsrecht).  Most of the towers which were part of the original fortifications are still visible in the city.  Osnabrück became a member of the Hanseatic League in the 12th century
column5: as well as a member of the Westphalian Federation of Cities.

column1: The history of the town in the later Middle Ages was recorded in a chronicle by Albert Suho
column2: one of Osnabrück's most important clerics in the 15th century.

column1: From 1561 to 1639 there was a considerable amount of social unrest and tension in Osnabrück due to the Protestant Reformation
column2: the Thirty Years' War and also witch hunting.  In 1582
column3: during the rule of Mayor Hammacher (1565–1588)
column4: 163 women were executed as alleged witches; most of them were burned alive. In total
column5: 276 women were executed
column6: along with 2 men who had been charged with wizardry.

column1: The first Lutheran services were held in Osnabrück in 1543. Over the next century
column2: Lutheranism expanded in the city and several Protestant bishops were elected. However
column3: the Catholic churches continued to operate
column4: and the city never became completely Lutheran. After the Thirty Years' War broke out
column5: a Catholic bishop was elected in 1623
column6: and the city was occupied by troops of the Catholic League in 1628. The Gymnasium Carolinum was upgraded to a Jesuit university in 1632
column7: but the university was closed a year later when the city was taken by Swedish troops and restored to Protestant control.

column1: Peace negotiations took place in Osnabrück and the nearby city of Münster from 1643 to 1648. The twin Treaties of Osnabrück and Münster
column2: collectively known as the Peace of Westphalia
column3: ended the Thirty Years' War. Osnabrück was officially recognized as bi-confessional Catholic and Lutheran. The prince-bishopric would be held alternately by a Catholic bishop and a Lutheran bishop. The Protestant bishop would be selected from the descendants of the Dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg
column4: with priority given to the cadets of what became the House of Hanover. From 1667
column5: prince-bishop Ernest Augustus
column7: built the new baroque palace. His son
column10: at the time residence of his younger brother

column2: renowned local jurist and social theorist Justus Möser wrote a highly influential constitutional history of the town
column3: the Osnabrücker Geschichte. Following the Seven Years' War
column4: the town's population fell below 6
column6: however an economic revival linked to the linen and tobacco industries caused it to rise again from the 1780s onwards.

column1: The French Revolutionary Wars brought Prussian troops into the city in 1795
column2: followed by the French in 1803. As a result
column3: the town's population was kept below 10
column4: 000 for the whole first decade of the 19th century. The Napoleonic period saw possession of the city change hands several times. Control of Osnabrück passed to the Electorate of Hanover in 1803 during the German Mediatisation
column5: and then briefly to the Kingdom of Prussia in 1806. From 1807 to 1810 the city was part of the Kingdom of Westphalia
column6: after which it passed to the First French Empire. After 1815
column7: it became part of the Kingdom of Hanover.

column1: The town's first railway line was built in 1855
column2: connecting it with Löhne. Further rail connections appeared over the following decades
column4: Cologne from 1871 and Hamburg from 1874. In 1866
column5: Osnabrück was annexed by Prussia after the Austro-Prussian War and administered as part of the Province of Hanover. Growth of the local economy and population was fuelled by expansion in the engineering and textile industries
column6: with the Hammersen Weaving Mill established in 1869 and the Osnabrücker Kupfer- und Drahtwerk metallurgical firm following in 1873. The later 19th century also saw growth in the number of schools and the arrival of electricity and modern sanitation.

column2: Osnabrück had over 70
column3: 000 inhabitants. The outbreak of the First World War necessitated food rationing; the Allied blockade and a harsh winter in 1917 led to further shortages. Following Germany's defeat in 1918
column4: a council made up of workers and soldiers took control during the November Revolution
column5: but were replaced by the new Weimar Republic the following year. Similarly to many other German cities
column6: Osnabrück experienced considerable inflation and unemployment in the 1920s
column8: 000 out of work by 1923 and nearly 14
column9: 000 receiving some form of government assistance by 1928.Politically
column10: Osnabrück in the 1920s was a stronghold of support for the Social Democrats and the Catholic Centre Party. However
column11: in the Reichstag elections of September 1930
column12: the Nazi Party received the greatest percentage of votes in the city (nearly 28%) – a more than seven-fold increase from their electoral performance in Osnabrück two years prior. During the campaigns prior to the two federal elections in 1932
column13: both Adolf Hitler and Joseph Goebbels made well-attended speeches in the city.

column1: Following the Nazis' seizure of power in January 1933
column2: Osnabrück was subjected to the implementation of National Socialist economic
column4: and social programmes. These resulted in economic growth for ethnic Germans who did not run afoul of the new regime
column5: and the town went from having over 10
column6: 000 unemployed in early 1933 to actually having a labour shortage five years later. However
column8: supporters of opposition parties and German Jews (who had experienced centuries of discrimination in the city) did not share in this growth and found themselves discriminated against
column9: imprisoned or forced to close their businesses and leave town. During the World War II
column10: both Jews and Romany were deported to concentration camps and extermination camps en masse.The war ended for Osnabrück on 4 April 1945
column11: when the XVII Corps of Montgomery's Second Army entered the city with little resistance. By the end of the war the city had been extensively bombed and required major reconstructive programmes following the war's end. Leading Nazis fled the city and the British appointed a new mayor
column13: during the allied occupation of Germany a British military governor
column14: Colonel Geoffrey Day was placed in charge of administering the city. Relations between the occupiers and the citizens of Osnabrück were generally peaceful
column15: though tensions existed; some minor fights broke out between British soldiers and local youths and some Osnabrückers resented the relationships that developed between the occupiers and local women. Additionally
column16: the British took over more than seventy homes for their own use by the middle of 1946. Amidst shortages
column17: the black market thrived and became one of the main focuses of police activity.After World War II West Germany realigned its states; Osnabrück became part of the new state of Lower Saxony in 1946. The British continued to maintain Osnabrück Garrison
column19: which at one point was the largest British garrison in the world
column21: 000 troops and employing around 500 local civilians. It was the target of a PIRA attack in 1996. Due to budget cuts
column22: the troops were withdrawn in 2008 and the property returned to the local government.After three centuries
column23: the city finally obtained its university when the government of Lower Saxony established the University of Osnabrück in 1974.

column1: Famous Osnabrück personalities include the writer Erich Maria Remarque and painters Friedrich Vordemberge-Gildewart (1899–1962) and Felix Nussbaum. Nussbaum has been honoured by Osnabrück in the form of a museum designed by Daniel Libeskind which opened in 1998; it was designed as a scaled-down version of Libeskind's own Jewish Museum in Berlin. The painter Paul Ehrhardt (1888–1981) with his local sujets was more of regional importance. The poet and scholar Johann Ernst Hanxleden was born in Osnabrück
column2: as were reggae musician Gentleman and DJ Robin Schulz. Victory Records and recording artists Waterdown are also based in Osnabrück.

column1: There are two higher education institutions in Osnabrück
column2: University of Osnabrück and Osnabrück University of Applied Sciences with more than 25
column3: 000 students. All of the types of German grammar schools are represented in the city
column4: including seven Gymnasien. Gymnasium Carolinum claims to be the oldest still existing school in Germany. Another well-known Gymnasium is the Ursulaschule
column5: a private school
column6: located directly opposite the Carolinum. The University of Osnabrück invested heavily in infrastructure to take on more students for the following years.

column1: It shares its airport with Münster.
Osnabrück Hauptbahnhof (central railway station) is an important rail travel hub. Travellers from the Netherlands heading to either Hamburg
column2: Denmark
column3: or Eastern Europe often have to change here.An extensive bus network operated by the Stadtwerke Osnabrück (public utility provider) provides public transport within the city and the surrounding region.[3] The central hub is situated on Neumarkt close to the main shopping street
column4: roughly 10 minutes' walk from the railway station.

column1: The city is divided into 23 districts:
Osnabrück is twinned with the city of Derby in England.
Previously Osnabrück had made contact with the British authorities as early as 1948
column2: hoping to find an English twin town and therefore achieve greater understanding with their former enemies in the Second World War. Unfortunately
column3: this attempt was unsuccessful and Osnabrück did not actively consider the idea again for another quarter-century. The twinning agreement with Derby was signed on 17 February 1976 in the historic Friedenssaal (Hall of Peace) in Osnabrück's town hall. Every year since then the two towns have exchanged envoys. Derby also has a square named after Osnabrück in honour of the twinning arrangement; this features an obelisk among other things.

column1: Osnabrück now has eleven twin and friendship cities: Derby (England)
column2: Angers (France)
column4: Çanakkale (Turkey)
column5: Tver (Russia)
column11: Gwangmyeong (Korea) and there are five envoys working at the twinning office in Osnabrück

column2: Derby and Osnabrück each appoint an envoy who spends twelve months in their respective twin city. The envoy's role is varied
column3: but primarily focuses on promoting the exchange of ideas between the two cities
column4: as well as acting as an educational and general information officer to promote awareness of the twinning scheme. The envoy's specific duties are numerous: translating
column5: giving talks and presentations to local societies and schools
column6: finding pen friends and short-term host families during work placements
column7: working in day-to-day contact to assist groups who want to get involved in twinning by identifying and approaching possible counterparts
column8: planning the Derby Day at the annual Maiwoche (May Week) festival

column1: The exchange of envoys between two cities is very unusual. The team of envoys in Osnabrück changes every year and Osnabrück also sends envoys to Derby
column2: Angers and Çanakkale. No other city in Germany participates in this exchange of envoys
column4: only one other city
column5: Wigan

column1: The twinning gives the inhabitants of both places the opportunity to interact with their international neighbours. Town twinning aims to enhance international understanding and break down social barriers.
